questions.text: Match these radiological angles and respective pathologies:
questions.solution:
The talocalcaneal angle, also known as the kite angle, refers to the angle between lines drawn down the axis of the talus and calcaneum measured on a weight-bearing foot radiograph. Normal range 25-40 degrees. Decreases in CTEV.

The Böhler angle,is also called the calcaneal angle or tuber joint angle. It is used in the assessment of intra-articular calcaneal fractures. Normal range 25-40 degrees.

Carrying angle is an acute angle formed between extended arm and forearm when palm is directed forward. This angle is formed due to the angulation of the articulating surfaces of the humerus with the forearm. Normal range 6-14 degrees. Reduces in cubitus varus. Increases in cubitus valgus.

Pauwel's angle is the angle between the line of a fracture of the neck of the femur and the horizontal as seen on an anterio-posterior radiograph. More the pauwel's angle, unstable the fracture and higher chances of non-union.

Topic: Radiological angles (X-ray)

Reference: J. Maheshwari’s 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics, page number. 369.

choices.text: Codman's triangle at the end of tumour

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl with swelling and pain in lower thigh was diagnosed to have primary osteosarcoma in histological examination post biopsy. Her x-ray of the involved femur bone will show all of these features except?
questions.solution:
Radiological examination: X-ray of osteo-sarcoma shows the following features:

  • An area of irregular destruction in the metaphysis, sometimes overshadowed by the new bone formation. The cortex overlying the lesion is eroded. There is new bone formation in the matrix of the tumour.
  • Periosteal reaction: As the tumour lifts the periosteum, it incites an intense periosteal reaction. The periosteal reaction in an osteosarcoma is irregular, unlike in osteomyelitis where it is smooth and in layers.
  • Codman’s triangle: A triangular area of subperiosteal new bone is seen at the tumour-host cortex junction at the ends of the tumour.
  • Sun-ray appearance: As the periosteum is unable to contain the tumour, the tumour grows into the overlying soft tissues. New bone is laid down along the blood vessels within the tumour growing centrifugally, giving rise to a ‘sun-ray appearance’ on the X-ray.
    • Fallen leaf sign is typically seen in Unicameral bone cyst (UBC)

Topic: Osteosarcoma

Reference: J. Maheshwari’s 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 240,251.

questions.text: A 15yr boy presents to you with complains of pain and swelling in left thigh. No history of injury or fever. X-ray of affected region is as follows. Probable diagnosis could be?
questions.solution:
Age – 15yr

Site – Femur (thigh)

Symptoms – Pain and swelling with no fever or trauma

On x-ray – Diaphyseal thickening of bone with new bone formation in layers (onion peel appearance)

All these features points towards Ewing's sarcoma.

  • It commonly occurs in long bones (in two-third cases), mainly in the femur and tibia. The tumour may begin anywhere, but diaphysis of the long bone is the most common site.
  • The tumour occurs between 10- 20 years of age.
  • The patient presents with pain and swelling.
  • There may be a history of trauma preceding onset, but it is usually incidental.
  • Often there is an associated fever, in which case it may be confused with osteomyelitis.
  • In a typical case, there is a lytic lesion in the medullary zone of the midshaft of a long bone, with cortical destruction and new bone formation in layers – onion-peel appearance

Chronic osteomyelitis will present with long standing history of fever along with local sinus and pus discharge. X-ray will show sequestrum and cortical irregularities.

Osteosarcoma typically arises from metaphyseal region of bone with radiological features like Codman's triangle and Sun ray appearance.

Hypertrophic non-union will present with history of trauma along with clear cut hypertrophy of bone along the non-united fracture site. No signs of fracture are there in the given x-ray.

Topic: Ewings sarcoma

Reference: J. Maheshwari’s 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 243.

questions.text: A practicing paediatrician referred a 10-year-old girl to an orthopaedician for his opinion with the diagnosis of vitamin C deficiency. The girl will likely have all of these clinical features except?
questions.solution:
• Scurvy is caused by deficiency of vitamin C (ascorbic acid). The result is decreased production and poor quality collagen.
  • In adults, it presents with swollen gums, gingivitis and abnormal bleeding tendencies typically producing perifollicular haemorrhages over the lower part of the thighs. Petechial haemorrhages and spontaneous bruises may occur anywhere in the body, but usually first in the lower extremities.
  • Treatment is by supplementation with vitamin C.
    • Pigeon chest is a clinical feature of rickets which is caused by Vitamin D deficiency.

Topic: Scurvy

Reference:. J. Maheshwari’s 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 315.

questions.text: Marble bone disease is common name for?
questions.solution:
• Osteopetrosis - This is a disorder characterised by dense but brittle bones (marble bones).
  • In a less severe, autosomal dominant variety the patient has a tendency to fracture.
  • In a severe, congenital, autosomal recessive variety, the child may have severe anaemia, jaw osteomyelitis and cranial nerve palsies.
  • Most of the patients of the latter type do not survive for long.

Topic: Osteopetrosis

Reference: J. Maheshwari’s 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number 317

choices.text: Supraspinatus, infraspinatus, Subscapularis and Teres minor
Subscapularis, Teres minor, Supraspinatus and Deltoid
Teres major, Teres minor, Supraspinatus and Infraspinatus
Infraspinatus, Teres minor, Subscapularis and Deltoid

questions.text: Muscles that form the "rotator cuff" around shoulder joint are?
questions.solution:
• The capsule of the shoulder joint is lax and permits freedom of movement.
  • The strong muscles surrounding the joint contribute a great deal to the stability of this joint.
  • The important among these are the ‘rotatorcuff’ muscles (supra-spinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, sub-scapularis).

Topic: Rotator cuff

Reference. J. Maheshwari’s 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 88.

questions.text: Pulled elbow is a condition related to which ligament in the elbow?
questions.solution:
• Pulled elbow - This condition occurs in children between 2-5 years of age.
  • The head of the radius is pulled partly out of the annular ligament when a child is lifted by the wrist.
  • The child starts crying and is unable to move the affected limb.
  • The forearm lies in an attitude of pronation.
  • There may be mild swelling at the elbow.
  • It is not possible to see the subluxated head on an X-ray because it is still cartilaginous; X-rays are taken only to rule out any other bony injury.
  • Treatment: The head is reduced by fully supinating the forearm and applying direct pressure over the head of the radius. A sudden click is heard or felt as the head goes back to its place. The child becomes comfortable and starts moving his elbow almost

Topic: Pulled elbow

Reference: J. Maheshwari’s 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 105.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presented with her 7 months old kid with complains of radial side wrist pain which gets aggravated upon lifting the child and doing other household works. Xray of wrist is normal but Finkelstein's test is positive. Name of the tendons involved in this condition are?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis in this case is deQuervain's tenosynovitis.

  • Usually occurs in female patients post pregnancy due to overuse of these tendons specially while lifting the child. Also commonly associated with hypothyroidism as well.
  • This is a condition characterised by pain and swelling over the radial styloid process.
  • It results from inflammation of the common sheath of abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis
  • On examination, the tenderness is localised to the radial styloid process.
  • Pain is aggravated by adducting the thumb across the palm and forcing ulnar deviation and on asking the patient to perform radial deviation against resistance (Finkelstein's test).
  • There may be a palpable thickening of the sheath.

de Quervain's tenosynovitis (affected tendon sheaths)

Topic: deQuervains tenosynovitis

Reference:. J. Maheshwari’s 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 303

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Tests for ACL – Anterior drawer test, Lachmann's test and Pivot shift test

Tests for PCL – Posterior drawer test and Dial test (when PCL injury is associated with postero-lateral corner injury)

Test for MCL - Valgus stress + at 30° knee flexion

Test for LCL - Varus stress + at 30° knee flexion

Topic: Knee ligament clinical examination

Reference. J. Maheshwari’s 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 149, 153.

questions.text: Identify the condition?
questions.solution:
• Trigger finger :
    • This is a condition resulting from the constriction of the fibrous digital sheath (A1 pulley), so that free gliding of the contained flexor tendon does not occur.
    • Initially, the only symptom is pain at the base of the affected finger, especially on trying to passively extend the finger. As the sheath further thickens, the contained tendon gets swollen proximal to it. The swollen segment of the tendon does not enter the sheath when an attempt is made to straighten the finger from the flexed position. This is called ‘locking of finger’. This locking can be overcome either by a strong effort in which case the finger extends with a snap-like trigger of a pistol or by extending the finger passively with other hand.
    • In early stages, local ultrasonic therapy provides In a long standing problem, a local injection of hydrocortisone relieves the pain. In some cases, splitting of the tight tendon sheath may be required.
  • DeQuervain's tenosynovitis - This is a condition characterised by pain and swelling over the radial styloid process. It results from inflammation of the common sheath of abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons.
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome - This is a syndrome characterised by the compression of the median nerve as it passes beneath the flexor retinaculum. The patient is generally a middle aged woman complaining of tingling, numbness or discomfort in the thumb and radial one and a half fingers i.e., in the median nerve distribution. Tingling is more prominent during sleep. Treatment is by dividing the flexor retinaculum, and thus decompressing the nerve.
  • Bowler's thumb - Bowler’s thumb is a perineural fibrosis caused by repetitious compression of the ulnar digital nerve of the thumb while grasping a bowling ball. Tingling and hyperesthesia around the pulp accompany this condition.

Topic:Trigger finger

Reference. J. Maheshwari’s 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number 303

questions.text: Pre-patellar bursitis is also known as?
questions.solution:
• Clergyman’s knee- Inflammation of infra -patellar bursa lying deep to the ligamentum patellae
  • Housemaid’s knee – Inflammation of pre-patellar bursa lying in front of the patella
  • Morrant-Baker's cyst – A posterior herniation of the synovial membrane in the popliteal fossa.
  • Osgood schlatter disease – Osteochondritis of tibial tubercle.

Topic: Pre -patellar bursitis

Reference: J. Maheshwari’s 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number 318, 355.

questions.text: Muscles of thenar eminence of hand includes all except?
questions.solution:
The muscles of the thenar eminence includes abductor pollicis brevis, opponens pollicis and flexor pollicis brevis. These are supplied by median nerve.

Adductor pollicis is supplied by ulnar nerve and is not a part of thenar group of muscles.

Muscles of hypothenar eminence includes abductor digiti minimi, flexor digiti minimi and opponens digiti minimi. These are also supplied by ulnar nerve.

Topic: Muscles of hand

Reference: J. Maheshwari’s 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 66

choices.text: Occurs in paralysis of the serratus anterior muscle in long thoracic nerve palsy
Occurs in paralysis of supraspinatus muscle in suprascapular nerve palsy
Occurs in paralysis of trapezius muscle in spinal accessory nerve palsy
Occurs in paralysis of rhomboid major muscle in paralysis of dorsal scapular nerve palsy

questions.text: The scapula bone of this gentleman became prominent when he was asked to push against a wall as shown in the image. Choose the correct statement from given options: Topic:Winging of scapula
questions.solution:
Winging of scapula: The vertebral border of the scapula becomes prominent when the patient tries to push against a wall. It occurs in paralysis of the serratus anterior muscle in long thoracic nerve palsy.

Topic: Winging of scapula

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics Page number. 63

questions.text: A 42-year-old female patient with family history of ankylosing spondylitis presents with neck pain and stiffness. She is also HLA-B27 positive just like her father. Which x-ray finding will not be there in her spine x-ray?
questions.solution:
X-ray of the lumbar spine in ankylosing spondilitis may show the following:

  • Squaring of vertebrae: The normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body is lost because of calcification of the anterior longitudinal ligament.
  • Loss of the lumbar lordosis.
  • Bridging 'osteophytes' (syndesmophytes).
  • Bamboo spine appearance.

In the peripheral joints, X-ray changes are similar to those seen in rheumatoid arthritis, except that there is formation of large osteophytes and peri-articular calcification. Bony ankylosis occurs commonly.

Rugger jersey spine is seen in renal osteodystrophy and is due to hyperparathyroidism.

Topic: Ankylosing spondylitis

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 293, 315

choices.text: Swelling of small joints of hands and wrist

questions.text: False about rheumatoid arthritis is?
questions.solution:
RA - Pain and stiffness in multiple joints (at least four), particularly in the morning, mark the beginning of the disease. This may be followed by frank symptoms of articular inflammation. The joints affected most commonly are the metacarpophalangeal joints, particularly that of the index finger.

Blood: It shows the following changes:

  • Elevated ESR
  • Low haemoglobin value
  • Rheumatoid factor (RF): This is an autoantibody directed against the Fc fragment of immunoglobulin G (IgG). RF can belong to IgM-RF, IgA-RF, or IgE-RF, but commonly done tests detect only the IgM type of RF.

Medical treatment: Medical treatment essentially consists of anti-rheumatic drugs. These consist of:

  1. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
  2. Disease modifying anti-rheumatic drugs (DMARDs)
  3. Steroids.

Topic: Rheumatoid arthritis

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number 287

questions.text: Investigation of choice for early diagnosis of Perthe's disease?
questions.solution:
Perthe's disease: In its early stages, before X-ray findings appear, Perthe's disease may resemble as transient synovitis, but further follow up shows characteristic X-ray changes of the former. Hence, investigation of choice to diagnose early Perthe's disease is MRI. MRI is an accurate imaging modality for the early diagnosis of LCPD and for visualizing the configuration of the femoral head and acetabulum.

Topic: Perthe's disease

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number 54

Referenc: Tachdjian's Pediatric Orthopaedics 5th edition page number:601

questions.text: Hangman's fracture involves which two vertebraes?
questions.solution:
Hangman's fracture: It is a fracture through the pedicle and lamina of C2 vertebra, with subluxation of C2 over C3, sustained in hanging.

Topic: Cervical spine fractures (hangman's fracture)

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 3

questions.text: A 70-year-old lady came for her regular yearly health check with complains of occasional body pain and upper body bending forward over time. Her spine x-ray showed wedging of vertebrae with severe osteoporosis. All these drugs can be used to treat her except?
questions.solution:
Medical treatment of osteoporosis consists of the following:

  • High protein diet: Many elderly patients suffer from malnutrition. Increasing their protein intake may increase the formation of organic matrix of the bone.
  • Calcium supplementation: Its role is doubtful, but may be helpful in cases with deficiency of calcium in their diet.
  • Androgens: These hormones have an anabolic effect on the protein matrix of bone, and in some instances ameliorate symptoms.
  • Estrogens: Estrogens have been shown to halt the progressive loss of bone mass in postmenopausal osteoporosis.
  • Vitamin D: This is given, in addition to the above, to increase calcium absorption from the gut.
  • Fluoride: The use of fluoride is still under study. It is supposed to make the crystallinity of the bone greater; thereby making bone resorption slower.
  • Bisphosphonates: These are used empty stomach. Oesophagitis is a troubling complication. IV options are also available.
  • Calcitonin: Parenteral administration of calcitonin helps in building up the bone mass and also acts as an analgesic.
  • Teriparatide: Recombinant PTH acts as anabolic agent increasing osteoblastic new bone formation.
  • Denosumab: Newly developed immunomodulator acts as antiresorptive agent.

Rituximab is also an immunomodulator and is used in treating inflammatory conditions like RA. It is one of the DMARD's.

Topic: Vertebral wedge fractures in osteoporosis

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number:309

choices.text: Callus is not formed in secondary healing
Seen in fractures managed with cast application

questions.text: False about secondary fracture healing is?
questions.solution:
Secondary fracture healing occurs in fractures where fracture haematoma is not disturbed, as in cases treated non-operatively (conservatively). There is healing, with callus formation, and can be evaluated on X-rays. It also occurs in fractures operated without disturbing the fracture haematoma (e.g. closed reduction internal fixation as seen in intra-medullary nailing and external fixators) and as in fractures fixed with relative stability (e.g. comminuted fractures treated with minimal invasive bridge plating).

Topic: Principles of fracture healing

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 11

questions.text: Greenstick fractures are commonly seen in?
questions.solution:
Physeal fractures are classified by the widely accepted Salter-Harris system (see below). Metaphyseal injuries in children are often different from their adult equivalents, due to the thick periosteum surrounding the relatively thin metaphyseal cortex. Metaphyseal fractures are generally classified according to fracture pattern and may be torus fractures, greenstick or incomplete fractures, or complete bicortical injuries.

Topic: Green-stick fractures

Reference: Rockwood and Wilkin's Fractures in Children's 8th edition, Page number. 222, 356, 358.

questions.text: All are markers of bone formation except?
questions.solution:
Markers of bone formation:

  1. Serum bone specific alkaline phosphatase
  2. Serum osteocalcin
  3. Serum peptide of type 1 collagen

Markers of bone resorption:

  1. Urine and serum cross-linked 'N' telopeptide
  2. Urine and serum cross-linked 'C' telopeptide
  3. Urine total free deoxypyridinoline

Topic: Markers of bone formation

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 12

questions.text: An 8year boy with blue eyes presents with his mother with history of minor injury in left leg. X-ray shows fresh fracture of left lower tibia with an old healed fracture of distal femur as well. Mother gives a history that his younger sister also had multiple fractures and died when she was just 2-year age. Likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Osteogenesis imperfecta is a condition characterised by tendency for frequent fractures because of weak and brittle bones.
  • It results from defective collagen synthesis, and thus affects other collagen containing soft tissues such as the skin, sclera, teeth, ligaments etc., as well.
  • The disease is commonly inherited as an autosomal dominant disorder, but a severe variant is known to occur where the inheritance is autosomal recessive.
  • Typically, the patient has a tendency for frequent fractures, usually with minimal trauma. Associated features are blue sclera, joint laxity and otosclerosis in adulthood.
  • Patients with the severe type do not survive beyond a few years, but those with the milder disease live their full life interrupted by frequent fractures.
  • The fractures unite normally but deformities secondary to malunion or joint contractures may occur. The tendency to fracture often reduces with age.
  1. Osteoporosis is a pathology of elderly population
  2. Battered baby syndrome will present with x-ray findings showing multiple fractures in different stages of healing along with skin bruises.
  3. Osteopetrosis shows dense sclerotic but brittle bones with features like anemia, jaw osteomyelitis and cranial nerve palsy.

Topic: Osteogenesis Imperfecta

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 316

choices.text: Can be associated with cervical ribs
An omovertebral bone is present in 50% cases
Mental retardation is a constant feature

questions.text: False about Sprengel's shoulder?
questions.solution:
• Sprengel deformity is characterized as a congenital upward elevation of the scapula in relation to the thoracic cage.
  • The scapula is commonly hypoplastic and misshapen.
  • Other congenital anomalies may be present, such as cervical ribs, malformations of ribs, and anomalies of the cervical vertebrae (Klippel- Feil syndrome).
  • In about half of patients, an extra ossicle, the omovertebral bone, is present; this is a rhomboidal plaque of cartilage and bone lying in a strong fascial sheath that extends from the superior angle of the scapula to the spinous process, lamina, or transverse process of one or more lower cervical vertebrae which prevents descent of scapula.

Topic: Sprengel's shoulder

Reference: Campbell's Operative Orthopaedics 14th edition Page number. 1231

questions.text: Fractures commonly seen in children are all except?
questions.solution:
Instead fracture of humeral head is commonly seen in old age due to fall on out-stretched hand as bones are weak due to osteoporosis.

Topic: Common Pediatric fractures

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 57

questions.text: A 34yr old gentleman presented with radius shaft non-union on right side. He had a history of RTA 6 months back, instead of consulting a doctor he visited to local bone setter who gave him simple crape bandage to wear. What can be the cause of non-union in this patient?
questions.solution:
Age of this patient is relatively young and supplements are not always required for fracture healing at this age. Moreover, had it been an open fracture then he would have primarily consulted an orthopaedic surgeon in view of the severity of injury due to the bleeding from open fracture.

Most common cause of non-union is inadequate immobilisation.

Factors affecting fracture union are:

  1. Age of the patient - More the age, poorer the bone quality, more chances of delayed/non union
  2. Type of bone - Flat and cancellous bones unite faster than tubular and cortical bones.
  3. Pattern of fracture - Spiral fractures unite faster than oblique fractures, which in turn unite faster than transverse fractures.
  4. Disturbed pathoanatomy - Changes may occur at the fracture site, and may hinder the normal healing process. These are: (i) soft tissue interposition; and (ii) ischaemic fracture ends.
  5. Type of reduction - Good apposition of the fracture results in faster union.
  6. Inadequate immobilisation - Most common cause of non-union
  7. Open fractures - Fracture hematoma drains and hence high chances of delayed/non-union
  8. Compression at fracture site - Compression enhances the rate of union in cancellous bone. In cortical bones, compression at the fracture site enhances rigidity of fixation, and possibly results in primary bone healing.

Topic: Principles of fracture healing

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 11
